author: oaklandmatt
content:
If you're trying to be a highly successful professional, you should do all of these things and be prepared to adjust on the fly.

I pretty much always have full songs, tracks, hooks, and concepts prepared. Much of the time, you won't use any of them on any given day. But good news: they're useful for future days.

I've had all of that prepared and then the artist and I just chat for five hours, then write a song on a piano.

I've had all that prepared and then cut song after song because the artist goes "what else do you have???"

Anecdote that might be helpful: I've been in with an artist all week. Me, another producer/writer, and her. The other producer/writer has his rig set up and he also writes topline. We usually bounce back and forth depending on what the song requires. We've all worked together before and we had the whole week blocked out so there's no pressure to perform on day one. But we did three songs on the first day because she just came in firing. The first song she came in with a title and we worked from scratch and knocked it out in an hour. The other producer made the track quick with some existing drum loops he had prepped for her, adding keys and horns as we wrote. Then she asked "do you have anything to play?" I played her a track hook I had prepared. She liked it and we powered through that one in another hour. Then we broke for lunch. We caught up. As we were finishing she mentioned this one kinda stupid and sassy idea she tried to bring into another session but the producers didn't like it. So we wrote that one and it was fire. I tapped out a tempo as she rapped the hook idea and just make a skeleton beat on the fly.

Being way over prepared is rarely going to hurt you.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I always tailor it to the artist in some way. It's a combination of making fresh ideas specifically for them and taking existing ideas that could work (sometimes reworking existing ideas). I never go into a session like an actual blind date where I don't know anything about them.

The challenge is always do I make something that sounds like what they've done, or do I make something that sounds like where they're going? That's impossible to answer. I've had success in major label POP artist sessions by having a 100 year old piano and specifically not playing tracks. Meaning, you never know if an artist is tired of doing the same shit. Because I have confidence in my skill as a producer, I'm happy to get an A+ ballad because I know I can turn it into whatever production I want. "In The Name Of Love" is my most successful example of this. It's an emotional 3 chord piano ballad that was produced into a festival EDM anthem. 

I've had the most success being prepared for all options. Mostly because that makes me flexible for what an artist is feeling that day, but also because the more stuff I make, the more music I'm making. If I prep for a session, I'm not working cold. The prep is also like a psychological and creative warm up for me. Prep makes me a better improviser.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
This is such a deep and cool topic. I’m in mastering now, so while I do a lot of collaboration it’s not quite what you’re getting at here but I’ve got a decent amount of experience in the room/tracking/producing. 

To me it is a matter of developing trust and belief with another person. My approach is to be brutally honest with people and let the chips fall where they may. When things are amazing, meh, or bad. As @BatMeckley said…you want the $10k mic. Don’t waste the time with anything in the middle.

So in short — I’d just tell them exactly what you wrote above. But I tend to be more on the extremes — I’d like to think that people come away from working with me with a deep-seated belief in themselves and their potential but also honest feedback about very specific things we can do better. I actively seek to challenge my collaborators (which I’m sure you do as well). I’ve found people really respond to this if it’s done with the clear intention to help both of us improve and with the curiosity of the potential in the art!

In short, I’m an extreme encourager but also a harsh critic (in a kind way). I never let someone give up on themselves if I can help it and show love for them by very specifically calling out how I recognize their potential but see areas for improvement!

I feel that I’ve always been able to tell when people do things like “lead with a compliment” or whatever. So that’s my POV on this whole topic…I just like people to be straight with me. When I have dealt with artists who clearly need the validation you’re speaking about….I’ll specifically call it out with something like “stop looking for validation you have the talent to do this now start believing in yourself”…etc. Seems sort of harsh but it really can cut to the chase and open up a deeper level of trust and communication.

Sometimes people don’t like this…and that’s all good too. Always lead with kindness and things work out. Depth > quantity

author: Zakhiggins
content:
1. I do it first thing in the morning when I wake up before things like my phone ruin my brain for the day. 

2. Make it a routine. I make some time before i have to go anywhere every morning to try and create something. When your brain gets used to the idea that you're going to that place at the same time every day, once you go there then the ideas flow better with time.

3. Understand it's ok to write something bad, with time good ones come. 

4. Understand that a song is never actually finished, it can only be abandoned wherever you chose to abandon it.

4.5. Understand that it's ok to figure out what a song means after you write it.

5. Understand that we're trying to make trees, not tables. (As in sometimes it's not healthy to keep refining something till it's too straight edge and the vitality is gone from it)

6. Said it already but saying it again, don't check your phone before you write

7. I don't always write lyrics. Sometimes i write a melody, sometimes a chord progression, sometimes lyrics. Every now and then i do a session of what i call Lego writing, where i try to see what lyrics i wrote before fit with what melody/chord progression etc. 

8. Oh and did i mention, it ruins my creativity to check my phone before i make anything? 

This is what works for me, hope it helps you!

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m sure we all share this struggle to some degree. I’ve got some projects that I’ve put many hours into, just to let them sit on a hard drive for years.

Co-writing has helped a lot, and has taken some ideas to places I never would have thought to go. The feeling that you have some moral obligation to your collaborators to finish is motivating. When you’re making art for yourself, it doesn’t benefit from those positive forces of peer pressure, and there’s a lack of constraints and no sense of urgency. 

I think making creative decisions is metabolically expensive. It’s easier to defer all decisions, which is why you see DAW-age producers committing to so little until the mix. In the same way you can defer the entire songwriting process, especially if you have someone else’s project or deadline to prioritize over your own.

To be both the creative mind and the executive finisher is a lot of exhausting context switching. Some options might be to split these responsibilities with someone else, or to dedicate separate time to each task. If someone hires me to print stems or solder a patchbay, the last thing I want to do is engage in creativity. But when I get inspired to write, I don’t want to stop and troubleshoot the plug-in that’s crashing the session.

Maybe like the divergence/convergence approach would be to set aside an hour or three at the end of your day to finish ideas you’ve already got brewing—set a timer and finish a song, or a verse. Or, even better yet, dedicate the *end* of your day to play and experimentation. Then the next morning, hopefully with fresh perspective, get in the mood to tie up loose ends and prepare your next steps. You’ve demonstrated that you’re good at wearing that hat for other artists, so you can do it for your songs, too. Just maybe not while you’re in the creative flow.

I’m not practicing what I preach, just brain-dumping. I definitely don’t have this figured out.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
This is a little of the top of my head, but I'll try and break it down like this. You're mostly going to get work/ collaborators for three reasons. 

The #1 is your work (great songs, in this case). If you make great shit, people will either hear it and reach out, or when you meet someone, you'll send each other things and they'll love your work and want to be a part of what you can do. no matter where you are in your career, this is #1 always always always. When I was starting out, I produced some of the best sounding records for local bands, so other local bands wanted to work with me. Now, I (or my manager, or my publisher) can send a spotify playlist with songs people know, and that helps get me gigs.

#2 is making shit with people you know personally. This is the best way to do it starting out since you don't have lots of great work out in the world. You need a little community of friends that you make shit with. I guess a lot of that will start moving online, but still the vast majority of great work gets done in person. Even during the pandemic, despite all the zoom writing session and remote work, most great stuff was still getting done in person. You gotta find your people and make things. Then you have the advantage of multiple people promoting your work.

#3 is the pure cold call hustle. It's TOUGH. It's a low percentage game no matter what you're trying to do (be it mixing or writing or producing or being an artist). You have to understand that you may get 1% response rate from people. It's not to say it doesn't have value, but if you want responses, you have to have a good pitch and sending out thousands of messages. But the other thing about this is that writing songs remotely frankly fucking sucks compared to doing it in person. Songwriting is such an in the moment emotional thing. Producing and mixing remotely is very very different that doing real time creative vulnerability. This #3 applies more to non-songwriting collaborations than anything else.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
when you write songs, you're creating intellectual property together. generally no one is hiring anyone, so there's usually no fees. as a producer, if you have a studio, that's just part of what you do and it's unusual when starting out to charge anyone for its use.

if an artist wants to release a song, and they want to use your recording (or any elements of it), you will negotiate a fee and royalty in exchange for the label owning your recording. an artist instead may want to engage another producer to produce your song. assuming you consent, you don't get any fee or royalty for the master recording. but you are still a co-writer on the song and thus a co-owner of the copyright (the intellectual property). you would retain all the royalties and rights from being a songwriter

author: ehutton21
content:
I also think most of my worst writing sessions happen when we don’t clear the air about what someone is looking for. If I’m writing with someone who doesn’t trust themselves as much or doesn’t feel comfortable leading a session because they’re pretty new to writing, I’ll try to be more of an active guide rather than a sounding board. I’ve also had people who get embarassed to write in front of others so I’ll just chill on my phone on the porch for them lmao. 

I think people who are writers and producers struggle to collaborator with that middle ground between seasoned pro/artist with very clear vision, and very “green” artist. They won’t feel comfortable having someone write a whole song for them but they don’t quite trust their own judgement yet either. I think the solution is to practice the idea of commitment.  Sometimes the best writing contribution is letting them do a lot of the lifting, and if the artist gets insecure or flustered, just ask them “well, how do you feel about the idea/line?” or “what about the line feels awkward?” That way you’re helping them to actually make decisions—now they’ll be able to write with you or anyone else, or completely solo.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes that's the way some people do it, but that's an old school method that is going away. 

There are SO many people who make songs that this method isn't super useful any more. Also, many more artists are co-writing their songs and not taking "outside" songs with the same frequency. 

The best way to get your songs recorded is to get in with the artists themselves. Then when you're in the studio working with the artist, you can pitch existing ideas you're working on. 

That's why we're always harping on the idea of making records with the people around you. You'll get used to the collaborative environment, you'll make a lot more work (because multiple people will be working on it), and you'll have more chances things get heard (because again, multiple people will be working on it). 

If the things you make with the people around you are truly great, they will get heard. That will be your gateway into more collaborations.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
If you're a producer and not a songwriter, and you want to be a songwriter in sessions, start writing songs on your own. Write 100% songs yourself, where you write all the lyrics and melodies and record your own vocal. The first 50 will probably be trash. That's ok. You don't have to show anyone. Just finish the songs and then write more. Put in the time and then you won't have any hesitation in a session because you'll be a songwriter.

Watch the Ed Sheeran doc for more inspo. He wrote 2-3 songs a day for ten years. That's why he's so good. There's no shortcut. Just start writing.

author: TheBlur
content:
Hey brother. My take on it; In a collaborative songwriting/ producer songwriter setting I ask for a playlist to be made showing what they are going for. Then having an exploratory meeting to discuss what’s in the playlist. Point to things and find common ground for where they are as a performer / songwriter comparative to the songs they chose. Sometimes it’s hard to express to a producer what you want. This a great way to start. Then, keep shaving off songs on that playlist until you guys have 5 - 10 songs that you both believe sounds like what you’re both going for.  

I’ve found this to be a Huge help when in the exploratory stages with a new artist.

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m still not sure I’m very good at this, but I didn’t know what to even offer as a co-writer until I’d had someone critique me, if that makes any sense. I mean really pull apart one of my songs word for word. Have you ever offered up one of your songs for that experience?

Perhaps the most value you can add is by looking at the song out of context, with fresh ears and no bias, and just determine whether or not the writer’s intention is clear and cohesive.

It’s a thing close to the heart, so you have to approach it with care (kinda like vocal producing). I can’t think of a time that I’ve ever offered lyrical input if a song I’m producing. It would have to be really detracting from the message.

It’s another thing altogether when you’re *invited* to offer a critique or help finish an idea…although sometimes I find that the invitation isn’t always an indication of open mindedness.

I also never slept well, needed to adjust tons of deadlines, and so I started to change things up. In some ways, feeling the urge to make moments happen is still part of how I work but I view my writing sessions as flexing the muscles rather than ideas until I know I have that feeling or moment where I am drawn to create, on top of whatever sessions I have. 

So nowadays, my strategy lately has been to change my goal orientation. Rather than thinking about my output in songs or ideas, I think about just trying to get myself into a creative rhythm and a flow state. If I ride my time out further than that, that’s awesome, but I try to make sure I have 3-4 hours a week of quality “flowing” writing time.

author: itaylerner
content:
Man, I have so many thoughts on this! I relate on so many levels. 100% agree with everything @NoahNeedleman said.

On the more zoomed in side of things, I have found a couple things to work extremely well. 

1.) specific positive feedback. “Great take” is fine. “Wow, the way you said this specific word really resonated with me, I remember feeling that way as a kid blah blah blah blah blah.” That specific positive feedback makes people feel safe, heard, and valued. “Cool idea, let’s keep exploring” feels really dismissive and tends to make people feel like they’re in boot camp which is not fun for anyone 

2.) mirroring emotions for validation. This might be a hot take but it’s what works for me: If they’re totally stoked about it you need to be stoked too. Just as stoked. Just fake it if you need to, ~especially~ in the early writing stages. You can always go back and revisit ideas, but once someone feels like their enthusiasm and creativity and taste is being questioned, it takes forever to rebuild that trust. Mirror their emotions, get excited, be specific. THEN, once you have established the kinship and spent your own time living with the idea and better understanding what would improve it, you can bring up “hey I was thinking and I have some ideas that might be able to make what you created hit even more!”

author: oaklandmatt

Yes x1000

Study the best things, even if they don't always seem to apply directly to what you're doing. 

Max Martin is maybe the best at making vocals sound A+. He is well known as a detail oriented, vocal-focused pop savant. He is often a part of every choice from writing lyrics and melody all the way to adjusting sibilance in the mix. His instincts for great melody and rhythm, paired with lyrics that sound good, is unmatched. And I say "sound good," because though I think many of the lyrics of his songs are meaningful (especially with the best lyric co-writers), the choice of words and how they are emphasized and enunciated is what separates him from everyone else. Do some YouTube searching on artists talking about working with Max Martin. You can learn a LOT about writing vocal from him.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
As I'm sure you already know , there is no such thing as enough. It's like how perfection doesn't exist. 

It may be easier to think of being a writer on a spectrum from hobbyist to full-time artist. The one end is the hobbyist who does it whenever they want and have time (other priorities take precedent). The other end is the artist who is compelled to do it and it has to turn it off in order to live a normal life.

Most people here are somewhere in between. For most of us, the key is to do a combination of two things:

1. Find every way possible at all times to joyfully write. Direct yourself toward it with how live. Write silly things for fun, have a guitar you like to play next to the place you always like to sit, write emotional things for catharsis, write with other people for the collaborative joy, sing in the shower, write on different instruments that feel inspiring, etc etc 

2. The harder part is developing habits and practices that keep you consistent. It's easy to write when it's fun. It's harder to write when it's not fun, and that's the time to make sure you're doing it. Daily practices, schedules, deadlines (self imposed or otherwise) are the best way to do this.

author: Deleted User
content: I deal with (unintentional) inconsistent tempo and some time even time signature/pulse pretty often when working with songwriters and artists. It seems to solve the problem when you tap your feet to the melody. Then you would realize that the tempo has changed. And count 1-2-3-4 or whatever the meter is. So you don’t end up unintentionally having an extra beat because of words and disrupt everything else. A lot of writers ask people for beats first for this reason, but if the melody doesn’t stand on it’s own- relying on the beats will do more harm than good in my opinion. They often end up being mediocre melodies from my experience because there’s already tons of subdivisions and grooves in the beat and the topliner is relying on that to drive the rhythmic feel. But also beats need to come in with pocket so there are space for the vocal melody to fit in. It would be good for writers to start without a beat or instrumentals and it would be good for beatmakers to practice leaving vocal pockets when starting with a beat first

author: Slow Hand
content:
Question for everyone: What is your approach to fostering the best creative output from a collaborator or a team member?

I'm writing/producing with an artist right now who has submitted a medium/excellent vocal concept for a song. As co-writer and producer I feel that this is a great jumping off point but it's not 100% of the way there and it will take some refinement. They're very excited about it. And they should be, because it's elegant and it's exciting.

My concern is that they may rest on their feelings of accomplishment and not give it that extra push and exploration that I believe it needs to truly shine.

What do you find is a good way to guide collaborators towards exploring an idea further and pushing themselves harder to really make something exceptional? I feel there are only so many ways that I can say "I really like what you've done, but let's explore some more stuff" without exhausting them or undermining the praise that I am giving them. How do I show them what's possible without micromanaging and writing it myself? It should come from within them and feel like it's theirs.

content: I’m not a lawyer, so don’t take my word, but these days it’s common for the original songwriters to receive a co-writing credit if their song is interpolated.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes. 

Covers (which have a definition of how much you can change and in what ways) don't require permission. You just give 100% of the publishing to the copyright owners. 

Interpolation (aka derivative works), require permission from the copyright owners. Along with permission, you negotiate their copyright ownership percentage (aka their co-writing share) of your new derivative work.

author: Deleted User
content:
A couple of things I always do before and during sessions

Have some things ready to play so collaborators can understand my background, and same with collaborators. I would ask them to play some things they did and grew up listening to so I can understand where they are coming from with decisions or comments they make. 

Always set up so it’s ready to record. have a phone running on record whenever music is played and the computer isn’t recording

Have a few small incomplete ideas at disposal before walking into the sessions. Could be a simple guitar chord progression with a little something on top, could be riff or banging drum patterns. Important thing here for me is to continue moving on to next ideas if I don’t get an immediate response (which is usually singing on top) and continue to work my way into it. 

I like to have full drums ready to go somewhere on my computer. So I can just import it in, and it will get people moving. Splice drum loops are fine too. Some sort of instant vibe is needed in my experience. Splice really helps with that, because then you don’t have people looking at the back of your head trying to dial in drums or synth patch for more than 5 minutes.

author: Deleted User
content:
I’ve tried different ways with hangs- I’m still figuring out. And I typically don’t touch lyrics anymore because I’ve found that I’m not that great at lyrics yet and if I don’t have a line (which I usually don’t….), it’s better to leave it be for the longevity of relationship because lyrics can be one of the most personal things in music making because… it is literal. If you are more lyrics person, I think you can get a lot of value out of hanging out. 

First thing is creating safe space- and it really depends on person to person. Some people never open up, some people can open up immediately. In my experience, the more experienced they are - the more they tend to be the latter. I think how much time you spend on it can be dependent on this. You mentioned wanting to be more intentional, one idea that came to my mind is communicating this from the get go. Obviously there are going to be times where bring this up can be weird in the beginning of the session, but it should get them to think about opening up as part of work at the very least. It needs to be done carefully of course

The other part of it is understanding the person themselves. Their general vibe and energy. It’s easier to tell with some folks, and it’s harder to know what kind of person it is with some other folks. regarding this, I find diving into work right away helps feel it out. my job is often to constantly create ideas and inspirations. I can often gather some information from how they respond to different ideas. 

Lastly, I used to spend a lot of time hanging up until very recently and I found it’s so much more productive to just work and bond through that experience. Nature of work calls for connecting on a personal level, but it doesn’t require it. I’ve been trying to take it easy on getting closer with people, and focusing on the overall experience of collaboration and it has been making sessions more productive. So I plan on sticking with this way for a bit and see how it goes!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The short answer is: you're a songwriter now too. This is a new part of your professional repertoire. This is great.

I made a similar transition from producing bands to doing co-writing sessions as a producer. You can still get hired as a producer or engineer (as I still do), but writing sessions are structured with different expectations and potential outcomes. 

When you participate in songwriting sessions, you are almost never getting paid up front as an engineer or producer. There are some cases where super rich people will pay for songwriting sessions, or artist with bigger budgets might get their label to pay a studio fee, but this will be a tiny minority of your writing sessions. 

Philosophically, the idea is that you're all creating something together that, if it's good enough, it will be released into the world in someway. But your experimenting and will make many ideas that don't cross that threshold. However, if any of the recordings of these song come out you will still get paid as a producer (/ engineer / mixer / whatever else you do on the final version). If no peace of the recording that you made when the song was written gets used, you will still participate as a songwriter on the copyright.

author: revolution
content:
i guess other forms of art like film or books often do require a lot of structure and thought in order to cohesively convey or execute a vision... even if the vision is fundamentally grounded on a seed of feeling or very specific idea. songs and music are so temporal and intuitive that it doesnt really require that necessarily. 

for better and worse, i tend to have this desire to seek out a 'scientific' nature in things. for me as a fan of films, i can often decipher or intuit the internal logic and intentionality that choreographs lights and angles and framing to create a moving feeling/painting. 

i do fully agree that fundamentally the only thing that can create this sense of 'spatial awareness' in a medium, or a sense of dialectic/causality between the subtle and intuitive, creative elements is experience and repetition; but i can't help but seek out knowledge or structure/self critique to my approach.

i think to that end, i should collaborate more with people who are experienced so i can accelerate my own learning if that's what i seek. i find myself always searching for this 'internal' awareness of intentionality, searching for the forces and patterns that make a system or experience exist and change how they do.

i am alwasy looking for this feeling of purpose or understanding of which steps are wanted/needed for me to take what ive created closer to its essence or my original vision. i think people understand this at the level of more technical creative aspects... for example mixing. ultimately the art is still to have a creative vision and executing that, but it's the experience and awareness to have intentionality and wisdom in how to execute that separates raw creativity/talent from a professional level of execution no? I think the same can be applied to more abstract skills like writing/songwriting.

i'm going to commit to writing new material everyday for a month and see what happens!
